context: This technique was able to continuously measure the concentration of many compounds that may be present at the outlet of the reactor. The chlorobenzene conversion was calculated from the amount in the inlet and outlet of the reactor and the carbon material balance was systematically checked on the basis of CB converted and CO and CO2 formed. The catalyst regeneration was carried out in a flowing air with the same GHSV (5000h−1) at 350°C for 5h. A blank test was performed at 350°C with pure SiO2 as an inert material and resulted in no chlorobenzene conversion.Catalyst characterization For the catalyst characterization, many techniques like the BET measurement of specific surface area, XRD, TPR, TG/DT analyses and SEM were used. BET specific surface area of samples (fresh, used and regenerated catalysts) was determined in a conventional static volume apparatus (Micromeritics ASAP 2020) operating with N2 adsorption at −196°C. The samples were initially degassed during 3h at 300°C. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalyst were obtained using a diffractometer (Inel cps 120) equipped with an iron anticathode (λ =1.936Å) and an ethane ionization curved detector allowing angles to be read simultaneously in the range 2θ =5–125°.

However, there is no additional information or distinct relationship presented between different instances of chlorobenzene, as it is treated uniformly throughout the discussion.
